   patient was initially unresponsive but with a pulse. Upon EMS arrival,
   he arrested; CPR was started, and a pulse was regained. However the
   patient went into cardiac arrest again. He was pulseless and
   non-breathing for approximately 5-10 minutes. ACLS protocol was started

   Assessment and Plan
   71M s/p fall with subsequent cardiac arrest, ? cord injury [**3-13**] dens
   fracture.
   Recommendations for neuroprotection:
   1.       Therapeutic Hypothermia: Pt had a cardiac arrest of unclear
   etiology, although may be related to a high cervical spine injury since
   pt has evidence of a dens fracture on CT scan. Induction of hypothermia
   carries a theoretical risk of coagulopathy and while this pat sustained
   trauma, there is currently no evidence of active hemorrhage. However,
   in discussion with the attending trauma surgeon, there is a concern for
   the possibility of delayed bleeding around site of cord injury if the
   pt becomes coagulopathic; therefore, will defer cooling for now,
   pending MRI of spine. If MRI is negative for cord edema, this issue
   could be revisited, although pt is now at least 5 hours out from
   initial arrest.
   2.       Avoid elevated ICP:
   -          HOB > 30 degrees
   -          Maintain normocarbia goal pCO2 35-40
   3.       Monitor for seizure activity:
                  -      Continuous EEG x 48 hrs
                  -       If sz activity on EEG, treat with benzos/AEDs as
   per Neurology recs
                  -       Neurology ICU/Epilepsy consult for EEG
   interpretation, prognosis
   We will continue to follow with primary team, please call/page with
   questions.
   [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) **] [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 963**], MD
   EM/CCM  Fellow
   Pager [**Numeric Identifier 8744**]

 INDICATION:  Dens fracture.

 COMPARISON:  Cervical spine CT scan dated [**2147-12-18**] at 11:24 a.m.

 TECHNIQUE:  Sagittal T1-weighted, T2-weighted, STIR, and diffusion-weighted
 images of the cervical spine were obtained, with axial gradient echo images
 from the craniocervical junction through C7-T1 interspace.

 FINDINGS:  Type II fracture of the dens is again seen, as described in detail
 in the preceding CT scan report.  There is associated disruption of the
 anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments.  There is also edema in the
 interspinous ligament at C1-2, extending into the posterior paravertebral soft
 tissues.  There is high T2 signal and swelling in the spinal cord at the level
 of C2 and the dens, consistent with acute edema.  While the dens fracture
 fragment is slightly retropulsed relative to the body of [**Name (NI) 267**], no significant
 narrowing of the spinal canal is seen.  There is a very small epidural
 hematoma posterior to the body of the dens, measuring 1.5 mm in thickness
 (image 3:10).

 Degenerative changes are present from C3-4, C6-7, with mild-to-moderate
 narrowing of the neural foramina due to uncovertebral and facet osteophytes.
 No significant spinal canal stenosis is seen.

 IMPRESSION:

 1.  Acute edema of the spinal cord at the level of C2 and the dens.

 2.  Disruption of the anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments at the
 level of the dens fracture.  Edema in the interspinous ligaments at C1-2.

 3.  Small anterior epidural hematoma at the level of the C2 body.  While the
 dens fracture fragment is slightly retropulsed relative to the [**Name (NI) 267**] body, there
 is no significant spinal canal narrowing.

 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 CT SCAN OF THE CHEST, ABDOMEN, AND PELVIS PERFORMED ON [**2147-12-18**].

 CLINICAL HISTORY:  60-year-old man status post fall from bicycle with
 asystolic cardiac arrest.  Evaluate for internal injuries.

 TECHNIQUE:
 MDCT was used to obtain contiguous axial images through the chest, abdomen,
 and pelvis following the administration of 130 cc Optiray IV contrast.
 Delayed imaging through the kidneys was also performed.  Coronal and sagittal
 reformations were provided.

 FINDINGS:

 CHEST:  An endotracheal tube is seen with its tip approximately 4.6 cm above
 the carina.  The tip of the NG tube is seen within the distal esophagus.
 Please note, the proximal NG tube is coiled in the oropharynx (seen on the
 concurrently performed CT cervical spine).  The mediastinal great vessels
 opacify normally.  There is a moderate amount of atherosclerotic calcification
 noted along the aortic arch.  There is dense calcification along the coronary
 arteries.  The heart is normal in size.  There is no pericardial effusion.  No
 lymphadenopathy.

 Dense consolidation is seen within the posterior lungs bilaterally with
 scattered air bronchograms most compatible with sequelae of aspiration.  There
 is no pneumothorax, hemothorax or evidence of lung contusion.

 ABDOMEN:  Streak artifact from a metallic EKG lead overlying the upper abdomen
 and right lung base somewhat limits evaluation through the liver dome.  Within
 the liver dome in segment VIII, there is patchy hypoattenuation which may
 reflect abnormal perfusion as the appearance is unusual for contusion.  There
 is no evidence of liver laceration or perihepatic fluid.  There is mild
 periportal edema, likely reflecting volume resuscitation.  The gallbladder is
 normal.  The spleen is intact.  Adrenal glands are unremarkable.  The right
 kidney is intact with parapelvic cysts noted.  The kidneys enhance
                                                             (Over)

 [**2147-12-18**] 11:14 AM
 CT CHEST W/CONTRAST; CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST                      Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 27045**]
 CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST
 Reason: trauma
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 symmetrically.  Along the left renal pelvis/ureteropelvic junction, there is a
 small amount of hematoma which surrounds the collecting system.  There is no
 contrast extravasation on the delayed images to suggest urinary tract
 disruption.  The source of this hematoma/bleeding is unclear, and the
 possibility of a parapelvic cyst rupture is considered.  There is no renal
 laceration or evidence of parenchymal injury.

 The abdominal aorta contains scattered atherosclerotic calcifications though
 is normal in caliber and major branch vessels appear widely patent.  There is
 no lymphadenopathy.

 The stomach and duodenum appear grossly unremarkable.

 PELVIS:  Loops of small bowel appear slightly prominent and gas-distende
 though there is no evidence of obstruction.  Large bowel contains a large
 amount of fecal material.  The appendix is normal.  Urinary bladder contains a
 Foley catheter.  The prostate gland measures 5.1 cm in transverse dimension.
 No free fluid is seen in the pelvis. Pelvic vessels contain scattered
 atherosclerotic calcification.

 BONE WINDOWS:  Acute left-sided rib fractures are seen involving the left
 second anterior rib, and anterolateral arch of the left 3 - 7th ribs  Old
 right-sided rib cage deformities are seen.  Vertebral body heights are
 preserved.  Schmorl's node likely result in concavity along the L2 superior
 endplate.  Degenerative change in the lumbar spine with facet arthropathy is
 noted.  The sternum is intact.  Bony pelvis appears intact.

 IMPRESSION:

 1.  Small hematoma along the left renal pelvis/UPJ without evidence of urinary
 tract disruption.

 2.  Bilateral posterior lung consolidations likely reflect the sequelae of
 aspiration.

 3.  Malpositioned NG tube with tip at the level of the distal esophagus.
 Recommendation for repositioning has been discussed with the trauma team.

 4.  Extensive atherosclerotic calcification along the coronary arteries.

 5.  Multiple left-sided rib fractures as detailed above.

 6.  Heterogeneous perfusion along the dome of the liver likely reflects
 abnormal perfusion and may be related to volume resuscitation and asystolic
 arrest.  Clinical correlation is advised.  No abnormality seen in this region
                                                             (Over)

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint: Unresponsive
   HPI:
     This is a 71 year old male who presents to ED in cardiac arrest s/p
   fall from bicycle.  Per witnesses report, the patient was riding his
   bike with a helmet at a low speed and hit a pot hole; he did not lose
   consciousness, but stood up and then suddenly collapsed. Per witnesses,
   patient was initially
   unresponsive but with a pulse. Upon EMS arrival, he arrested; CPR was
   started, and a pulse was regained. However the patient went into
   cardiac arrest again. He was pulseless and non-breathing for
   approximately 5-10 minutes. ACLS protocol was started and a pulse was
   found. In ED, he remains intubated, in NSR and on norepi for blood
   pressure. Found to have Acute type 2 dens fracture. Admitted to TICU
   for further management.
